comment.author: 32741315@N06
comment._content:
Hi Dan

I'm definitely hearing the feedback on the panoramas. If you follow the 'Find out more' link on each of the descriptions, you'll get to a zoomable version of the image, which means you can see heaps more detail. 

We've only just launched these zoomable images (since we loaded these images to The Commons) - I'll be rewriting all those link texts to tell people about them asap.

cheers, Courtney
comment.authorname: National Library NZ on The Commons

comment.author: 32741315@N06
comment._content: Hi liam.martin - you can use a zoomable image on the Timeframes website People who like this photo might also like to check out a watercolour painting of the same area by an early NZ artist and scientist John Buchanan, "Milford Sound, looking north-west from Freshwater Basin" (1863). It's one of my favourite works of NZ art, and it's held by the Hocken Library at the University of Otago. You might have to accept viewing condition first, here's a link to the online image.
comment.authorname: National Library NZ on The Commons

comment.author: 32741315@N06
comment._content:
Thanks so much Fi. Feedback like that is heart-warming. 

And thanks for the shout-out to the photographers (James Ring, William Williams, Thomas Frederick Scales, William Price, David De Maus and Robert Percy Moore so far) - it is amazing to see people responding to their work like this.
comment.authorname: National Library NZ on The Commons

comment.author: 67342267@N00
comment._content: This is taken by Robert Percy Moore using a circuit camera - these are very cool cameras using a very large negative up to 1metere long. The camera swivels as the film rolls past a slot during the exposure. His original prints were contact prints, sumptous detail! Check it out: www.archives.gov.on.ca/english/exhibits/connon/camera.htm

comment.author: 32741315@N06
comment._content:
Thanks so much for adding this detail, dianaholga. 

I've been looking closely at the zoomable images on our Timeframes website (there's a link to each of these in the description under each photograph) and 'sumptuous' is exactly the right word for the detail that can be seen, even in the digitised versions.
comment.authorname: National Library NZ on The Commons
